int_desc_ht:
['Page 66:
[¬s]"Children in the treatment groups received daily
homework assignments that were color-coded for easy
identification from other school papers. All the
homework-intervention assignments were printed on pale
green paper. The paper was printed on both sides. One
side had reading activities and the other side had math
activities. The objectives being practiced were listed
on the page above the activities with brief directions
to the parent. A place for the parent's signature
appeared at the top of the page. The homework
activities were designed by the researcher specifically
to foster growth in one or more of the objectives to be
evaluated on the Georgia Criterion Reference Test,
(see appendix for a listing of GCRT objectives). First
grade texts, GCRT objectives, and materials developed
by the DeKalb County AIM Project were used as guides
for developing these activities (see appendix for
examples of homework activities).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: NA
int_objec_info: The objectives were to improve the reading and maths ability of children by involving parents in their homework
int_training_ht:
['Page 63:
[¬s]"At the meeting for the parents of the children of
the treatment group, the parents were given a complete
explanation of the project, its objectives, and how
they could help. The parents were given a copy of the
Georgia Criterion Reference Test objectives. The
objectives were explained and demonstrated. Parents
were told that the scores from the GCRT would be used
as an important Judge of their child's readiness for
second grade in the spring. Parents were then given a
brief summary of research findings on the importance
they play in their child's learning and the value and
purpose of homework.[¬e]"']
int_when_info: The children were given daily homework
int_dur_ht: ['Page 62:\n[¬s]"The intervention phase of the project was from\nOctober 17, 1988 through April 5, 1988.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 64:\n[¬s]"Homework Intervention assignments were sent hone\nevery day, Monday through Friday.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 89:
[¬s]"It is evident that some force was having a
positive effect on the El group. The most likely
factors were the treatment, the teacher, or a
combination of these two factors. Since no significant
positive change was seen in treatment group E2 in[¬e]"', 'Page 90:
[¬s]"reading or math, it will be impossible for the
researcher to conclude that the treatment alone made a
significant difference for treatment group El. The
cause of the definite positive movement seen by group
El will remain clouded. Since teacher philosophy has
an affect on the way a teacher responds to parents and
the type of relationship built between them, it is
quite possible teacher El may have been more successful
in implementing the program. It may also be that
teachers differed in teaching abilities.[¬e]"', 'Page 91:
[¬s]"Group El returned 82% of all
the homework assigned. Group E2 returned 83% of al 1
the homework assigned.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht:
['Page 59:
[¬s]"Children were placed into homerooms by
the lead teacher and principal using test scores
achieved on the DeKalb Math End-of-Readlness Test and
the Macmillan Series R Reading Readiness Test. All
subjects were given these tests during the first week
of first grade. The tests were used to place children
with similar scores into the same homeroom, therefore,
the children were grouped by performance on these tests
creating a bias toward the comparison groups who had
higher entering academic achievement scores.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The parent training program was identical to that published
by Barkley (1987) and was oﬀered to parents in a group format
over 10 weekly sessions beginning in October of each year.
Following these weekly sessions, monthly booster sessions were
oﬀered to these parents from January to May of the kin-
dergarten year. All parent training groups were conducted by
the same child psychologist who was trained by the ﬁrst author
and who had 5 years experience in this treatment program.
The parent training program is comprised of sessions teaching
parents: (1) the causes ofdeﬁant behavior; (2) positive attending
skills and praising; (3) attending to child compliance and
improving parental command eﬀectiveness; (4) rewarding
children for nondisruptive behavior; (5) setting up a home
token system; (6) time out and response cost (ﬁnes in token
system); (7) managing children in public places with think
aloud-think ahead strategies.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Results showed
that parent training produced no signiﬁcant treatment eﬀects, probably owing largely to
poor attendance.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"A comparison was then made of those parents who did not attend parent training (Nl25) with parents who did attend at least one training session (Nl51) on measures of child and parent characteristics assessed at the initial evaluation of these children."
"Results indi-
cated that the nonattendees did not diﬀer signiﬁcantly
from the attendees in the age of the children (4.7 vs. 4.8
yrs.), the children’s IQ (94 vs. 97), the mothers’ ages (28
vs. 29 yrs.), the fathers’ ages (32 vs. 32 yrs.), or the fathers’[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"social class (43 vs. 40 on Hollingshead). Nor were any
diﬀerences found on either teacher CBCL ratings of
attention problems or aggression, or on measures of
parental marital satisfaction, as assessed by the Locke-
Wallace Marital Adjustment Test (Locke & Wallace,
1959; see also Barkley, 1981), or parental depression and
general parental psychopathology, as assessed by the
Symptom Checklist 90 Revised (Derogatis, 1986). The
families who failed to attend training had both mothers
and fathers who were signiﬁcantly less educated than
those families who did attend training [mothers: 12 vs. 13
yrs., t (74)lk2.15, pl.035; fathers: 11.5 vs. 12.6 yrs.,
t (52)lk2.55, pl.014]. Surprisingly, the children of
the nonattendees were rated as being signiﬁcantly less
inattentive and aggressive by their parents on the CBCL
than were the children of families who attended train-
ing [CBCL Attention T-score: 57.4 vs. 63.8, t(74)l
k3.18, pl.002; CBCL Aggression T-score: 63.9 vs.
69.2, t(74)lk2.37, pl.021]. All of this suggests that
although nonattendees may have been less educated,
these parents may also have had less incentive to attend
training given that their children were viewed by them as
signiﬁcantly less problematic in their behavior than were
the children of families who attended parent training.[¬e]"']
int_fidel_info: Though this includes the treatment group that combined parent training and classroom treatment

int_desc_ht:
['Page 89:
[¬s]"The district reading specialist, kindergarten teachers, and Title I aids
administered a screening instrument during kindergarten registration in April 2003
(Appendix E). The screening instrument was used to place children into program
and non-program status.
The independent variable (phonological awareness instruction) was
administered daily for 2 hours June 9 - July 4, 2003, to 93 children that scored
below 54 points on the screening instrument. Children received explicit
phonological awareness instruction from trained early childhood educators. The
program was designed to build on existing family literacy practices and to increase
phonological awareness skills including: word comparison, rhyming, syllable
segmentation, sentence segmentation, initial sounds, onsets/rimes segmentation and
blending, and phoneme manipulation, segmentation and blending. Parents were
invited to the program one day per week to receive training specific to home[¬e]"', 'Page 90:
[¬s]"interventions in phonological awareness (Appendix C). The parents were asked to
implement phonological awareness activities into the daily homework of their
child.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to determine if prekindergarten children who
participated in an explicit phonological-awareness training program, which
included their parents as teachers, entered kindergarten at a reading readiness level
higher than would have been expected had they not participated in the program.
An additional goal of this research was to demonstrate the utility of the regression
discontinuity design in program evaluation.[¬e]"']

['Page 38:
[¬s]"The LCSD Kindergarten
Readiness Screening was used to assign children to program or nonprogram status.
A cut score was established and the children who scored below the cut point on the
LCSD Kindergarten Readiness Screening (93 children) received treatment in the
program. Those children, who scored above the cut point on the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (244 children) were placed in the comparison
group.[¬e]"']
base_diff_info: The study groups were decided on a threshold for scores in a schooling preparedness test.
comp_anal_ht:
['Page 38:
[¬s]"Prekindergarten children living in Logan, Utah, attended kindergarten
registration with their parent(s) or guardian(s) at the LCSD District Office during
April 2003. During the registration process, every child participated in the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (Appendix E)."
"The LCSD Kindergarten
Readiness Screening was used to assign children to program or nonprogram status.
A cut score was established and the children who scored below the cut point on the
LCSD Kindergarten Readiness Screening (93 children) received treatment in the
program. Those children, who scored above the cut point on the LCSD
Kindergarten Readiness Screening (244 children) were placed in the comparison
group. This method of assignment, adherence to a cut score, was consistent with
the regression discontinuity (RD) design used in the study.[¬e]"']
comp_anal_info: The children lived in the catchment area for the same schools and received the same test, this was what was needed to qualify for the RDD.

comp_var_rep_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The four groups were formed from 20 boys and 20 girls, ranging in age from 3
years 5 months to 4 years 5 months. The children had been assessed on Raven’s
Progressive Matrices, Reynell Comprehension and Expressive Language Scales and
the English Picture Vocabulary Test (EPVT). These 40 children were selected so that
each group member was closely matched on these measures to one member of each of
the other groups. The four groups were thus made up of 10 matched quartets. There
were no significant differences (t-test) between any pair of groups in the initial
assessments.[¬e]"']

int_desc_info: it's a structured parent involvment literacy program  ... teachers encouraged the students to take home literature backpacks, each containing a cassette player, audiotape, and Spanish literature book. They were asked to write their reactions to the audiotapes in a journal. Their parents were asked to share stories of their lives with their children and to initial the pages of the children's journals after reading them. The students' families were visited by two community aides, who encouraged the parents to read Spanish literature books once a night to their children. Parents were also encouraged to listen to the audiotapes from the backpack materials.  programme components in detail (p.47-50)  community home visits, Spanish literature books, writing journals, telling stories, literature backpacks
int_objec_ht:
['Page 47:
[¬s]"from Parlier, California, a community situated approximately
26 miles southeast of Fresno, California. Parlier is a
rural agrarian community with a population of approximately
8,000. From April to October, farm workers from Texas and
Mexico migrate to Parlier's migrant labor camp, thus
increasing the population to 9,000. The Parlier Unified
School District serves a student population of 2,300. The
ethnic makeup of the district makes it unique in California
because it is 99.7% Hispanic. Most of the residents'
incomes are below poverty level. Because English is rarely
used at home, over 50% of the children in the district are
identified as limited-English-proficient (LEP) or non-[¬e]"', 'Page 59:

knowledgeable in ways that could help their children improve

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"In the dialogic reading program, each child was provided with a total of 8 books. Hints for prompt questions and recall prompts were added in each book. One book and the pictures[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]"for the corresponding book were distributed each week by teachers. Parents were encouraged to read each book twice in a week for 15 minutes each time with their children. The first book, a dialogic reading guideline, a calendar checklist, and pictures for that book were initially given to the parents. The parents were trained individually through a 20-minute training session by phone before the reading intervention started. They were trained to use special strategies and the materials given to encourage their children to be active storytellers in parent-child reading. The fundamental reading technique in dialogic reading is the PEER sequence in parent-child reading. The parent prompts the child to say something about the storybook, evaluates the child\x92s response, expands the child\x92s responses by rephrasing and adding information, and repeats the prompt to ensure the child has learned from the expansion.[¬e]"']

"In all cases, the dependent variable was an adjusted posttest score, control- ling for child age and pretest."
"For each of the
four dependent variables, pretest was a significant covariate, accounting for 10%
to 56% of variance in posttest scores. The association between pre- and posttest
was strongest for expressive vocabulary and weakest for phonemic awareness.[¬e]"']
comp_var_rep_ht:
['Page 11:

four dependent variables, pretest was a significant covariate, accounting for 10%
to 56% of variance in posttest scores. The association between pre- and posttest

was a significant covariate for phonemic awareness and emergent writing, with
older children having higher posttest scores. Age was not a significant covariate
for expressive vocabulary, which was measured in an age-normed metric.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:

int_name_info: There is no official name given to the intervention
int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"The intervention procedure in respect of the two school-based groups
(A and B) was one devised by the author in 1972 and now in operation in eight
Renfrewshire schools at the request of head teachers.
The experimental preschool children and their mothers were asked to attend
the school each Thursday at 3 p.m. from February, 1974, to June, 1974. While
the children played under the supervision of auxiliaries, the mothers selected a
book to read at home to the children from a supply provided by the primary
adviser and the county library. The mothers then had tea with the three infants’
teachers who had volunteered for the project, in an effort to enhance relations
between mothers and teachers. After tea, mothers met in groups chaired by
teachers. Three mothers had two children involved and each teacher chaired a
random group of 12 mothers.
In addition to story books, each mother was
provided each week with a typed unit of a programme devised by the child
guidance department for mothers to administer at home. This programme
prescribes materials likely to be available in all homes and deals with general
vocabulary, simple number and relationships of time, space and size. Mothers
were asked to spend a total of 30 minutes a day on the book and programme.
At the group meetings each mother was asked to say how she fared with the
child during the previous week and received suggestions from the other members.
Discussion at group meetings often ranged over wider aspects of education
and child rearing and mothers appeared to be sufficiently reinforced by these
meetings to persist in the programme.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"The five sessions were carefully designed to encompass elements such as story planning, modelling, trialling the equipment, exploring different animation techniques, filming, and editing. Each element was matched to one of the 5Rs (a learning dispositions framework) developed by CfL 2 : Readiness, Resourcefulness, Resilience, Responsibility and Reflectiveness (Wall et al. 2010). The progression through the programme was carefully mapped to ensure that the metacognitive elements and the animation process were closely associated and therefore maximised opportunities for transfer. This process was standardised using a number of resources including goal and reflection sheets that allowed the families to record their learning experiences. [¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]" There were two aspects to the intervention. The first involved training teachers in how to embed metacognitive approaches in their work, and how to continue to effectively and strategically involve parents. This training took place over a day and was provided by a consultant. The second component focused on parental engagement and offered families the opportunity to participate in a series of facilitated workshops where children and parents work together to create an animated film.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Mind the Gap seeks to create better learners by harnessing the power of effective metacognition strategies. This is based on the idea that effective learning depends on skills, attitudes and dispositions to learning, and that these can themselves be learned.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"Staff development: All intervention schools were invited to send two teachers to a regional training day led by Jackie Beere, an independent consultant with established expertise in the field of Learning to Learn, working in partnership with CfL. This day’s training focused on how to embed approaches for developing metacognition in their work, and how to develop a strategic approach to effective parental engagement. The training covered why metacognitive development is important, including some of the[¬e]"', 'Page 14:\n[¬s]"theoretical background in this area, as well as a practical consideration of requirements in individual school contexts, enabling teachers to apply their learning to their own work. Teachers were also provided with access to resources and references to use in school.[¬e]"']
int_approach_info: Focus is on teacher training (so teachers can embed metacognitive approaches in their teaching) and parental workshops where children and parents create an animated film. No specification about teaching approach.
int_when_info: Animation sessions took place after school.
int_who_info: Practitioners came in to deliver animation sessions.

This translates into a per child cost of roughly £130. The cost of teacher training was typically an additional £195 per delegate.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"PEEP group sessions take place at a variety of easily accessible locations throughout the community. These are either based in the PEEP Center or at local playgroups, schools, and family centers. All sessions contain the same fundamental elements: Circle time: Music, rhyme, and rhythm are deeply embedded within the curriculum and are seen as "a powerful interactive medium in relationships" (PEEP, 2003). All families are offered audiotapes and a songbook containing the songs and rhymes used in the program. Talking time: An opportunity is provided for adults to discuss information and ideas, to share experiences, and to offer support. Story time: Daily sharing of books is a fundamental aspect of the curriculum and is modeled in every session. Book sharing: Books are available for parents to share with their children during the group sessions and to take home. Home activities: Practical suggestions are provided for games and activities that are closely related to and support the curriculum."
"Borrowing time: A library of play packs that contain a book and other stimulating materials are offered on a
weekly basis.
Throughout PEEP sessions, PEEP leaders model for parents the different ways of reading books to their children by
paying particular attention, for example, to (1) varying the tone of their voices, (2) reading the title of the story and
the names of authors and illustrators, (3) following the text with their ﬁnger, and (4) asking questions for
comprehension while they are reading the story. Parents are also encouraged to read to their children as much as
possible, and families are provided with a story pack on a weekly basis.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"PEEP set out its aim as being
to effect a positive change in the educational achievement of a community of children, especially in the ﬁeld of
literacy, by a series of interventions beginning at the time of the child's birth until his or her entry into school[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"PEEP had the following aims:
1. To promote parents' and carers' awareness of children's very early learning and development through making
the most of everyday activities and interactions.
2. To support parents/carers in their relationships with their children to enhance children's self-esteem.
3. To afﬁrm the crucial role of parents/carers as children's ﬁrst educators.
4. To support parents/carers in the development of their children's literacy and numeracy.
5. To support parents/carers so that they can encourage the development of positive learning dispositions.
6. To promote and support parents' and carers' lifelong learning.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"parent involvement (PI) intervention\nand the reciprocal peer tutoring (RPT)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Students in all three conditions participated in two 45-min mathematics sessions per week over an average intervention pe- riod of 10 weeks. The study was conducted in a regularly equipped classroom, and sessions were directed by the school psychology intern assigned to the school and by two classroom assistants."
"The resulting intervention was a home-based, PI interven-
tion that was designed to enhance the parents' role as
supporter and motivator of students' academic effort and
success (Ehrlich, 1981). The intervention involved regular
home-school contacts indicating the level of students' aca-
demic effort in classroom learning activities and parent-
initiated celebrations of students' academic initiative and
persistence.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"The present study examined the effects of a home-based, parent involvement (PI) intervention
and the reciprocal peer tutoring (RPT) intervention on the self-concept and mathematics
achievement of academically at-risk urban elementary school students.[¬e]"']
int_prov_info: John W. Fantuzzo, Gwendolyn Y. Davis, and Marika D. Ginsburg University of Pennsylvania

int_training_info: Limited training was provided to parents involved in the PI element of the project  to share a menu of effective strategies that parents used in prior years (see Heller & Fantuzzo, 1993), and (d) to help the parent(s) design a PI strategy that they were willing and able to carry out given the aforementioned barriers Training was also provided for children involved in the RPT group  Children in this condition were randomly paired in dyads and were given guidelines that allowed them to manage their own group reward contingencies. During two 45-min training sessions, assistants demonstrated the intervention procedures and allowed dyads to practice until each dyad could accurately follow the procedures

int_desc_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Dialogic reading involves families\nreading with their children rather than to their children[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The aim of our study was to implement a dialogic reading
programme with a group of at-risk children in the year
prior to formal schooling, and to assess its effectiveness
by comparing literacy achievements in Year 1 of the
experimental group with the literacy achievements of a
control group of children who were similarly at risk of
reading failure.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"An initial meeting with each experimental group family
took place in the family home. A trained research assistant
presented the families with videotaped instruction
exemplifying good practice in dialogic reading. This video
recording was developed by one of the authors in a pilot
study reported elsewhere (Fielding-Barnsley, 2000). Three
families are shown on the videotape, with each family
concentrating on a different aspect of dialogic reading.
There are examples emphasising rhyme, vocabulary and
CAP. Each family also received written information about
the dialogic reading process, thereby extending the visual
information provided on the videotape. This was in the form
of a four-page pamphlet developed by The University of
New England School of Psychology’s Early Literacy
Team (Byrne, Fielding-Barnsley, Delaland, Mackay and
Black, 1999). This pamphlet contains sections on: ‘How to
promote pre-reading skills in your child; Read with your
child; Let your child tell the story; Play with speech
sounds: Rhyme and alliteration; Teach your child about
the alphabet; and Teach your child about the sounds
that make up words … and how letters stand for these
sounds.’[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"Each family was provided with a selection of eight picture
books, a Parents’ Handbook (Barrs and Ellis, 1998), and a
reading together record form. The books were selected
from The Reading Together Series (Barrs and Ellis, 1998)
and included a variety of genres: rhyme, fictional stories,
factual texts, alphabet books and traditional songs. The
books were selected to fulfil the requirements of the study
in that they provided for development of rhyme awareness
(phonological awareness), alphabet knowledge, alliteration
(phonemic awareness) and rich vocabulary.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Families were asked to read each book with their child at\nleast five times during the eight-week intervention.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Each experimental family was asked to read each of
eight books with their children at least five times during the
eight-week intervention (requiring reading 1.4 books per
day). The average number of readings per book was 6.5[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"In most cases a parent did most reading at the
children’s bedtime but older siblings also did some after
school[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 52:\n[¬s]"Parental Involvement Program[¬e]"', 'Page 54:\n[¬s]"Teacher Corps, a federally funded program assigned to Drew School for a two year cycle in 1976-77. Teacher Corps was established in the U . S. O ffice of Education through the enactment of T itle V, Section 511 of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Its objectives are to strengthen the educational opportunities available to children in areas with concentrations of low-income families and to encourage colleges and universities to broaden their programs of teacher preparation. The main assignment of the Teacher Corps program a t Drew School was to develop the community component.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: No specific name however the intervention provided training for parents in supporting their children through the new English Language Arts Standards
int_desc_ht:
['Page 16:
[¬s]"The parents were taught the steps
in the writing process as follows: (1) Pre-writing, (2) First draft, (3) Revising,
(4) Editing, (5) Second draft and final revision, and (6) Publication. Parents
were shown samples of students’ writing at each of the stages in the pro\xad
cess. Activities for each step will be discussed in the procedure section[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: NA
int_training_ht:
['Page 18:
[¬s]"Phase Three: At the same time that the students were given their third
topic, Making Something That I Enjoyed, the parents attended a formal two-
hour training session. First, they were informed of the English Language Arts
Standards, then taught the steps of the writing process. This procedure was
followed to enable parents to understand that writing is a gradual and recur\xad
sive process that develops in stages from pre-writing to publication with many
opportunities for revising and recreating. During this time the researchers
shared with the parents many practical ways of helping them to enhance
their child’s ability to think about, talk about, and share with their children
experiences that were meaningful to them. Parents were given samples of
their child’s work and asked to comment on the areas they thought were in
need of improvement."
"The second hour of the training session involved the same procedures
that were used with the children to acquaint them with all six components
of the writing rubric and how to arrive at a holistic score. Parents were given
a script to guide their interaction with the students. They were taught how to
critique their child’s work, not their child.
Parents responded to each composition based on the specific compo\xad
nent of the writing rubric. Finally, they were given three samples and were
asked to score the samples on all six criteria. A discussion followed each
scoring until parents arrived at a consensus. It was explained to parents that
their child would be coming home in the next few days with a composition
for them to score. After parents scored the writing piece, they were to dis\xad
cuss with their child the areas of strengths and those needing improvement
on the writing sample. No additional writing or corrections were to take place
at home. Parents were only to discuss the child’s writing piece based on the
criteria in the rubric.[¬e]"']
int_part_info: The focus on parents is to achieve improved outcomes for the children
int_approach_info: for  children in school for parents attending 2 hr workshop
int_when_info: Assumed outside of working hours for parents but not stated
int_who_info: in the case of the children

['Page 19:

analysis of variance was performed. The first factor treatment involved be-

group. The experimental group had 97 students and the control group had
70 students. The within-subjects factor was “Phase” consisting of three phases.
The means of the groups within each phase are presented in Table 1.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" Reciprocal Peer Tutoring (RPT) intervention combined with a parent involvement intervention [¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 66:
[¬s]"RPT Only Condition This condition was designed to combine the benefits of structured peer tutoring and interdependent group reward contingency procedures. Children were paired in dyads and were taught specific techniques which enabled them to act as instructional partners for one another and manage their own group reward contingencies.[¬e]"', 'Page 71:
[¬s]"The sequence of events for parent and child participants in the RPT plus PI group was as follows. When children earned their team goals, they were given attractive "reward certificates" which they brought home to their parents indicating that they were entitled to a "home reward". Home rewards were determined by both parents and their children, and included things such as food treats, parent-child activities, or special privileges at home (e.g., staying up late or having a friend spend the night). Parents signed their names to the certificates, and indicated the type of reward provided, when it was provided, and whether or not they encountered any problems. Parents were encouraged to provide rewards to their children within a day or two after the rewards were earned. Children returned completed reward certificates to research aides. Parents were individually contacted by telephone within a few days after their children earned rewards to discuss[¬e]"', 'Page 72:
[¬s]"the rewards children received, answer any parent questions, and respond to any parent suggestions. Additionally, parents and research aides exchanged ideas about different types of rewards which could be provided. Records were kept of the specific home rewards each child received throughout the intervention. Records were also kept documenting additional types of parent involvement: (a) occasions when parents came into the project classroom to observe their children engaged in collaborative learning, and (b) occasions when parents provided assistance.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 52:\n[¬s]"Collaborative learning and parent involvement are well- supported in the literature as interventions which have [¬e]"', 'Page 53:\n[¬s]"been linked with numerous achievement and adjustment benefits for school-age children. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of the RPT intervention and a parent involvement intervention on the mathematics achievement and school adjustment of academically at-risk school-age students.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 66:
[¬s]"RPT Only Condition"
" Two 45-minute training sessions were used to teach students how to use procedures. Research aides modeled procedures and used instructional prompts until students could follow the procedures on their own .[¬e]"', 'Page 69:
[¬s]"RPT plus Parent Involvement (PI) Condition[¬e]"']

int_leng_ht: ['Page 55:\n[¬s]"Each intervention session was 45 minutes in length[¬e]"']
int_fidel_ht:
['Page 61:
[¬s]" The integrity of the experimental conditions was assessed by direct observation of student and staff adherence to intervention procedures for both RPT conditions and students' understanding of the tasks that were specific to their condition. Random checks of 50% of the sessions served to assess the accuracy of staff and student implementation. Checklists were used by observers to indicate percent adherence. The degree to which students' understood the procedures for their condition was assessed by a 15-item questionnaire. This questionnaire contained the specific procedures included across both experimental conditions. Students were asked to indicate whether they engaged in these activities in their condition by circling true Reproduced with permission of the copyright owner. Further reproduction prohibited w ithout permission.[¬e]"', 'Page 62:
[¬s]"51 statements. One-half of the items included were correct procedures for a given condition and one-half represented incorrect procedures. The questionnaire was completed by students midway through the intervention, and individual accuracy percentages were computed. A copy of the treatment integrity questionnaire appears in Appendix G."
"Treatment integrity checks were also conducted on the parent involvment intervention. Telephone calls were made to determine if parents actually carried out their predetermined strategies for supporting their children's success in the RPT intervention.[¬e]"', 'Page 65:
[¬s]"The following steps were taken to minimize the confounds of research aide, classroom setting, and class time. For each day of intervention, classes were held in the same classroom in successive sessions (rotating through the groups of dyads) with the same pair of research aides supervising all sessions. Additionally, the class times for the groups were rotated on a weekly basis.[¬e]"']

int_cost_ht: ['Page 38:\n[¬s]"The three-year average annual cost per pupil7 including all trial participants recruited into the two treated groups independent of attendance status (n=1,2488) is £641 for the incentivised and £280 for the unincentivised group. Table 20 sets this out in more detail. It is important to note that set-up costs have been divided equally between incentivised and unincentivised groups, although some costs arguably would be incurred in full if only one group was run (for example, the event for headteachers)."\n"When these figures are disaggregated by local authority, the results are quite different: respectively £754 and £366 for incentivised and unincentivised groups in Area 1, and £549 and £207 for Area 2 (see Table 21 and Table 22, respectively). The reason for the differences in per pupil costs is due to three interacting factors: 1. Staff costs were lower in Area 2. 2. The greater recruitment success in Area 2 reduced the impact of some annual fixed costs. 3. The lower attendance rate in Area 2 reduced expenditure on incentives for the incentivised group.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"nts in a control group and 177 students whose parents participated in an experimental program that included parent education sessions, at-school parent/child ac- tivities, and at-home book-mediated activities. The intervention, Early Access to Success in Education (Project EASE), was designed to increase the frequency and quality of language interactions through book-centered activities and to give parents information about and opportunities for engagement in their children's developing literacy abilities. Parents received information about ways to strengthen vo- cabulary, extend narrative understanding, develop letter recognition and sound awareness, produce narrative retellings, and understand exposition. Measures of home literacy support were collected from parents and a battery of language and literacy tests were adminis- tered to intervention and comparison children prior to the interven- tion and at its conclusion. Children whose families engaged in the at- school and at-home activities made significantly greater gains in lan- guage scores as measured on subtests of vocabulary, story comprehension, and sequencing in story-telling than comparison children. Th[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Intervention procedure The intervention began in September with a series of orientation sessions for parents whose children were in the intervention classrooms. Each family received an explanatory letter from the district administration outlin- ing the program and met with the intervention teachers individually to learn about the scope and intention of the program (only three parents refused to participate). Parents were invited to an evening meeting where the program was further explained and the proposed process of parental involvement outlined. At that meeting an overview of the year's program and an explanation of the research principles involved were given. Concurrently, control families were informed that the project was being carried out, and all agreed to allow their children to be tested as part of a comparison group. The parent training sessions were organized in five 1-month units; in each unit a parent coaching session was led by a trained parent educator, working from a scripted discussion outline to assure fidelity across schools. All relevant information was also included in a take-home guide so that the concepts addressed in the sessions could be reviewed at will. Each parent education session was followed immediately by opportunities to en- gage in structured parent-child activities designed to pro- vide practice in the desired interaction. Each of the subsequent 3 weeks, the teachers sent home a set of scripted activities incorporating the principles that were the focus for that month. These structured activities in- cluded scripted interactions and demonstrations of how to engage children in extended discussions surrounding a book. Each book to be used in the at-home activities was specifically selected because its content and text design offered lexical richness, extended discourse opp"
"ties, and interesting ideas to talk about. Thus, the scripted parent-child interactions fostered the types of high-quality language interactions that research has shown to be ef- fective in promoting language development. The se- quence, including a parent education session during which literacy activities were modeled and opportunities to practice those activities with the child were given and then scripted activities that were sent home from school every week, was repeated for each of the five interven- tion units. (See Appendices A through E for outlines of the five unit[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"fect of an inter- vention program, Project EASE, designed to provide par- ents both with a theoretical understanding of how to help their children and with scaffolded interactive practices to facilitate their children\'s early literacy development.[¬e]"']

training, the children were occupied by a drawing activity.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Procedural reliability was conducted to ensure consis\xad
tent administration of the child eligibility and early literacy
assessments. A trained research assistant randomly
selected and scored 25% of the audiotaped pre- and
posttest assessment sessions. This amount was selected
based on recommendations presented by Wolery and
Holcombe (1993), in which they suggest that procedural
measures should be conducted for 25% of cases. Each
session was examined in its entirety and was scored to
examine the administrator’s consistency in (a) presenting
instructions, (b) sequencing tasks, (c) administering items,
and (d) providing feedback. Reliability scores on indi\xad
vidual assessment sessions ranged from 96% to 100%. The
overall reliability score was 99.6%."
"Assessment of the extent to which parents implemented
the reading program in their homes was conducted.
Audiotapes were returned using cassette mailers at the end
of each week. A total of 109 tapes (out of a possible 112)
were returned. Seventy percent (306) of the 436 home
reading sessions that were recorded and submitted were
analyzed. Sessions were chosen randomly. For each session,
the following features were examined: (a) session date, (b)
number of books read (i.e., 0, 1, or 2), (c) duration of
reading session, and (d) parental use (or non-use) of verbal
print-referencing behaviors (parents’ use of nonverbal print
references could not be determined via audiotape).
Analysis of control group sessions indicated that during
96% of sessions (156 out of 162), both target books were
read in their entirety. Similarly, analysis of experimental
group sessions indicated that both target books were read
in their entirety during 95% of sessions (137 out of 144)"
"An important consideration in this study was parents’
use of print-referencing behaviors, and more specifically,
that experimental group parents used these behaviors as
instructed and that control group parents did not use these
behaviors. Home reading sessions were thus analyzed to
determine the extent to which parents in both groups used
verbal print-referencing behaviors. Sessions were analyzed
to document parents’ use of specific print-referencing key
words, including word, spell, letter, and sentence, to name
a few. The raw frequency with which parents used these
print-referencing key words during each book reading was
tabulated.
For the experimental reading sessions, fidelity measures
indicated that during 97% of the sessions examined (140
out of 144), parents used at least nine verbal print\xad
referencing behaviors during the book reading. This
demonstrated that print-referencing strategies were used to
a high degree in the experimental group. Control group
reading sessions were also examined to ensure that parents
in this group were not using these strategies. Analysis of[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"the reading sessions in the control group found that print
references occurred in only 3% of the sessions (5 out of
162), demonstrating that few references occurred in this
group spontaneously.
To ensure that this process for assessing treatment
fidelity was reliable, a second individual randomly selected
and scored 10% of the taped sessions to determine point-
by-point interscorer agreement in fidelity coding. Agree\xad
ment scores ranged from 88% to 100%, with a mean
agreement score of 98% across sessions (SD = 4.4).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 26:
[¬s]"The present study evaluated the effectiveness of an academic intervention focusing on parental supervision of a nightly study routine. The intervention provided parents with structured methods to reinforce cooperation during a routine study time and successful completion of the child’s homework; methods to supervise and help manage their child’s routine study time; and support to resolve difficulties that the parents may have experienced."
"Treatment effects were hypothesized to have a direct effect on school engagement,
which was then hypothesized to affect math skills, math grade, social interactions, and[¬e]"', 'Page 27:
[¬s]"antisocial behavior. This model of treatment effects is presented in Figure 1. In addition
to school engagement predicting math skills, antisocial behavior, and social interactions,
the baseline measures of these variables are also expected to contribute to the model.
Finally, changes in math grade are expected to be predicted by both School Engagement
and Math Skills."
"The treatment was hypothesized to improve school engagement for the treatment
group. It was also hypothesized that school engagement would predict school
performance, antisocial behavior, and social interactions. Thus, if the intervention had
direct effects on school engagement, the intervention would also result in indirect effects on
school performance, antisocial behavior, and social interactions.[¬e]"', 'Page 46:
[¬s]"The independent variable was the type of group, treatment or control, to which
subjects were assigned. Subjects in the treatment group received a parent-directed
intervention that focused on the establishment and the parental supervision of a routine
study time, with special attention directed to mathematics homework. The intervention
consisted of four main components. The first component was an instructional program.
during which each parent received information, modeling, feedback, and written materials.
The purpose of the instructional program was to develop the parent’s skills and the child’s
cooperation for conducting a routine study time. The instruction was delivered during two
meetings held either at the family’s home or at the school."
"The second component was the
parental monitoring of the child’s routine study time. Study-time contracts and study-time
checklists were used to facilitate parental monitoring and the child’s compliance. The third
component was a home-school communication process that was facilitated by using
teachers’ voice mail and a school calendar maintained by the students. The final
component was an ongoing support and consultation in the form of weekly telephone calls
to the parents. In addition to these four main components, two areas of general
considerations for supervising homework were discussed with the parents.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Students and their parents were assigned randomly to an intervention group or
a control group. The intervention consisted of four main components, a video-based
instructional program establishing a routine study-time, parental monitoring of the child’s
routine study time, a home-school communication process using the teachers’ voice mail
and the students’ school calendar, and ongoing support and consultation via weekly
telephone calls to the parents.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 39:
[¬s]"research
has shown that students who are at-risk for developing patterns of antisocial behavior can
show improved academic performance when provided with academically focused
interventions."
"Moreover, some studies have found improved school behavior (Coie & Krehbiel, 1984;
Filipczak & Wodarski, 1979), attendance (Filipczak & Wodarski, 1979), and sociometric
ratings (Coie & Krehbiel, 1984).[¬e]"', 'Page 40:
[¬s]"The second main conclusion that can be drawn from this literature review is that
parental involvement can improve student performance on homework."
"The purpose of the present study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a parent
directed intervention for improving academic performance of students demonstrating
academic difficulties and high risk antisocial behavior. In doing so, this study attempted
to address questions that could not be answered by the research presented in the literature
review. The primary question of the present study is: Does an academic intervention that
provides parents with strategies and resources for monitoring their children’s homework,
improve school engagement of children identified as exhibiting antisocial behaviors and
low academic success?[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 46:
[¬s]"The instructional program was based on a videotape program and accompanying
materials (a study-time contract and reading materials) entitled Study Skills for Success[¬e]"', 'Page 47:
[¬s]"(Forgatch, 1991). This video program is based on materials from the Parents and
Adolescents Living Together books by Patterson and Forgatch (1987) and Forgatch and
Patterson (1989) and is about 25 minutes long. Specifically, the video focused on
establishing a routine study time to be conducted consistently at least 5 days per week,
parental monitoring of homework completion, parental reinforcement of student
cooperation through incentives, and increasing home-school communication."
"The Study Skills for Success program was modified for the present study by
replacing direct contact between the parents and the teachers with indirect contact through
the teachers’ voice mail system. Throughout the video, two families are followed through
the process of implementing a routine study time and improving homework completion.
Difficulties and solutions are highlighted as each family works out the program unique to
its family circumstances. Written materials (Forgatch, 1991) made to accompany the
video, and covering the same issues as the video, also were provided to the parents. This
program has been used in a previous study that demonstrated positive effects on parental
supervision of homework and children’s report of homework quality (Forgatch & Ramsey,
1994).[¬e]"', 'Page 49:
[¬s]"During the first instructional meeting, parents and students were taught how to use
the calendar. This instruction focused on two tasks. The first task was the need for the
student to record, on a daily basis, homework assignments for each class. Students and
parents were shown the appropriate space in the calendar for recording the information on
each class. They also were instructed that the student should make daily records of
homework assignments, even if there was no homework assignment that day. If there was
no assignment for a day, the students were instructed to make a note that there was "no
assignment." The parents also were instructed that it was their job to check the school
calendar on a nightly basis to ensure that their child was recording the homework
assignments. Checking the calendar gave the parents an opportunity to make sure the
child was working on the assigned homework. Parents also could verify the correctness of
the child’s notes for the homework assignments by using the math teacher’s voice mail[¬e]"', 'Page 50:
[¬s]"system."
"Support and Consultation
Each parent in the treatment group was contacted by telephone each week of the
intervention after the parents completed the instructional sessions. The purpose of these
calls was to answer questions, provide suggestions, and encourage success. All calls had a
similar structure. The researcher asked: (a) how the study routine was going, (b) how well
the child was complying with the study routine, and (c) what questions the parent had.[¬e]"', 'Page 51:
[¬s]"The researcher took a positive approach by focusing on successes, and working collaboratively to decide on solutions to any difficulties that the parent experienced. During these calls, the parent also was asked each of the Study Time Checklist questions. Asking these questions gave added structure and focus to the telephone call, gave the researcher the opportunity to focus on successes, and allowed the researcher and the parent to identify areas of difficulty."
"The instructional program consisted of two sessions conducted individually for
each treatment family during the first 2 weeks of the study. During the first session, the
parents and their child viewed the Study Skills for Success video (Forgatch, 1991).
Following the video tape presentation, the parent and the child were given the opportunity
to discuss how they believed the program would work in their family. Following this
discussion, the written materials that accompanied the video were presented. These written[¬e]"', 'Page 52:
[¬s]"materials were discussed with the parent and the child with reference to the video to
highlight critical aspects of the program (e.g., consistent implementation of routine study
time, parental supervision). Areas that the parent or the child identified as potential
barriers or strengths were focused on during this discussion. The parent and the child were
asked to brainstorm and try to agree on possible solutions to barriers that they identified.
After the discussion of the written materials, the parent was asked to setup a routine study
time at home as soon as possible, and a second meeting was scheduled. The first session
ranged from 1 hour to 1 1/2 hours in duration."
"Only the parent attended the second meeting. The purpose of the second session
was to review the materials from the first session, and to provide support and
problem-solving strategies for problems that the parents might be experiencing. Second
meetings were conducted only after the parent reported that they had had the opportunity
to implement the study program. Efforts were made to conduct the second meeting within
1 week of the first meeting. However, for some families this was not possible. The time
between the first meeting and the second meeting ranged from 3 days to 15 days (mean =
6.8 days). During the second session, the researcher led a discussion on how the routine
study time was working in that family’s house. Parents were encouraged to focus on their
successes, and brainstorm solutions for difficulties they were having. The duration of the
second session ranged from 1/2 hour to 1 hour.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 63:
[¬s]"Measures of Treatment Integrity
Three measures of treatment integrity were administered to the parents in the
treatment group: a quiz given to parents before and after the parent training session
(Appendix J), records of which parents used the teachers’ voice-mail system, and the
Homework Time Checklist administered to the parent during the weekly telephone
check-up. The quiz consisted of 6
questions, worth a total of 9 points, to which parents
were asked to provide written responses. The quiz was used to assess the degree to which
parents understood the materials taught in the parent training session. This quiz was given
twice to all treatment families, once at the beginning of the first meeting and once at the
beginning of the second meeting. It took parents about 5 minutes to complete the quiz.[¬e]"', 'Page 63:
[¬s]"The second measure of treatment integrity was the number of messages left on the
teachers’ voice-mail system during each week of the study. This measured number of[¬e]"', 'Page 64:
[¬s]"parents who used the teachers’ voice-mail to monitor the accuracy of their child’s
homework calendar. It should be noted that some parents may have used the voice-mail
system without leaving the message.
The Study Time Checklist was administered to the same parent of each family
during the weekly telephone check-up. During these telephone conversations parents were
asked to consider only the last 24 hours and to respond to each of the 8
checklist. A global score was calculated based on the first 6
items on the
items in the checklist,
representing the integrity with which the parent was implementing the program. This
treatment integrity score was the proportion of the six parent behaviors in the checklist,
across all telephone calls, to which parents responded "yes".[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"instructors began each event by explaining the goals of the event—to encourage families to have fun reading and discussing books at home and to use reading comprehension strategies that reinforced skills taught by teachers. After the introduction, children and parents watched a video show- ing adult–child dyads reading and discussing books. First, the video included a bilingual family in which a mother read a fiction book with her daughter; asked questions before, during, and after the reading; and re-read interesting and difficult passages. The mother–child dyad read a narrative book about the 4th of July holiday, and the mother also asked questions about the book before, during, and after the reading in English. Second, the video showed a father reading a nonfiction book about baseball with his son and engaging in a discussion about the book in Spanish. Similar to the mother–daughter dyad, the father prompted the son to think about questions to ask before, during, and after the"
"After viewing the videos, the instructors asked parents at the family literacy event to discuss and to write down on a piece of paper what they were able to “see” and “hear” the child and parent do during the reading. Next, instructors gave families an opportunity to read a fiction book and a nonfiction book in English and Spanish, to practice using the comprehension and oral reading strategies, and to complete the reading postcards used by teachers in their classroom lessons."
"In the second and third sessions, the activities in the first lesson
were repeated, and parents were taught to use additional activities
from the book[¬e]"']

[¬s]" Groups of parents and their children (usually around 5–8 families in each group) attend eight weekly 2.5-hour group sessions after school, delivered by trained local partners. Sessions are designed to encourage good home routines around mealtimes, bedtimes and homework with the intention that this will improve the behaviour of the attending pupils, freeing up the teacher to focus on learning to the benefit of the whole class. int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"Training to deliver FAST takes place over two days prior to commencement of the eight-week programme and is delivered by SCUK FAST trainers, or FAST freelance trainers, who have been accredited by Middlesex University."\n"SCUK assigns each school a FAST trainer. The trainer delivers the training, and supports the school with partner and family recruitment (Phase 1). They attend FAST sessions during weeks one, three, and eight in a quality assurance role and to provided support where needed. They also hold a three- hour review session after week eight with the site’s FAST delivery team (Phase 2). About a month after the eight-week programme, the trainer leads a session to gain feedback from parents and staff, and share their programme cycle evaluation report put together by Middlesex University (Phase 3).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"The program consists of 43 sessions, each one lasting 30 min, with three sessions being scheduled per week. 1 The participating families received all program materials free of charge, along with accompanying instruction booklets informing parents and children about the session structure and providing guidance for program imple- mentation and practical recommendations (e.g., on the time and place of sessions). The parent booklet further provided advice on how to deal with problems such as children\x92s reading errors. It was recommended that one parent should work through the whole program with the child, but it was also possible for fathers and mothers to alternate. Essentially, each session consisted of two parts: (a) guided reading aloud (with the additional element of parents as models) and (b) an implicit strategy-training component that focused on metacognitive strategies and elaboration of text content, again with parents as models, and involves a scaffolding component, with parents helping children to answer questions or answering questions themselves. Each individual session was highly structured and standardized comprising: (a) Shared reading aloud of a text for about 15 min to support \x1fuency and vocabulary; the materials in- dicated whether each text should be read by the child or the parent. (b) A general metacognitive question to explicitly train comprehension and vocabulary monitoring: \x91\x91Was there anything in the text that you didn\x92t understand? Or were there any new words? Try to clear up any problems together before going on\x92\x92. (c) Three to four basic comprehension questions to ensure basic understanding (propositional text representation) and to implicitly induce metacognitive comprehension monitoring via comprehension monitoring questions (e.g., \x91\x91Why was Monica [the main character] sad when she and her family moved to Romania?\x92\x92)[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"It aims to foster important prerequisites of reading (vocabulary, word ﬂuency in terms of fast
and accurate word identiﬁcation, knowledge and use of metacognitive strategies, and reading motivation), as well as
text comprehension skills and the ability to elaborate text content in oral communication in dialogue with a partner.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"We now turn to our second research question on program implementation: Is it possible to implement the parente
child program as intended in the conceptual framework in terms of accuracy of implementation, conditions of imple-
mentation, and implementation processes? With respect to accuracy of implementation, analyses of session protocols
and post-program questionnaires indicated that, on average, families conducted 35 of the 43 sessions scheduled
(SD ¼ 8)—an implementation rate of 81.4%. Moreover, 31% of families did not skip a single session. In line with
the recommendations given in the program manual, families spent an average of 30.09 min (SD ¼ 8.38) on each ses-
sion. In contrast to the recommendations, however, 77.9% of the families reported that they did not conduct three ses-
sions per week. Instead, most families tended to complete two sessions per week, thereby extending the total duration
of the program. Regarding the conditions of implementation, children worked with one parent as recommended in
94.8% of cases. However, 23.3% of families reported that other persons were often present during the sessions, al-
though they had been advised to ﬁnd a time and place for the child and one parent to work together alone. The three
scales in the session protocols assessing the implementation processes indicated (a) that the collaboration/working
process was judged to be successful (M¼ 4.12, SD¼ .46) on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very) from the parental
perspective, (b) that, on average, the children perceived the structures and processes of the program positively
(M¼ 4.51, SD¼ .40) on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very), and (c) that few difﬁculties were reported by parents
(M¼ 1.69; SD¼ .38) on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 5 (very). Fig. 2 illustrates the average ratings of the 43 sessions on
these three scales.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"The ﬁrst research question addressed was whether families were willing to participate in a voluntary reading pro-
gram in their free time and whether they actually completed it. The overall participation rate turned out to be low: 34%
of all families approached by letter registered for participation, and only 13% of all families conducted the program as
intended.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Students were de\x1ened as program participants if the protocols returned showed that they had completed more than 15 of the 43 intended sessions."
"Families\x92 willingness to participate and dropout rates were measured on the basis of registration \x1egures and the session protocols in which participants recorded whether or not each session was conducted. Accuracy of implemen- tation and implementation conditions were measured by reference to the session protocols and post-program question- naires, which provided data on the number, frequency, and duration of sessions, session participants, and implementation processes. The following three scales from the session protocols assessed implementation processes.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]" It is intended to be a low-cost and low-effort process, involving text messages being sent directly by schools\x97via their existing school information management system (\x91SIMS\x92, Schoolcomms or similar system)\x97to parents\x92 mobile phones at specific time-points and intervals during the school year. Parents were not made aware of the specific type of text content to expect, but rather that they would receive text messages about their child\x92s progress in school."
"For the purpose of this evaluation, the programme was delivered from September 2014 to July 2015 and focused on the subjects of English, mathematics and science. The type of text messages that parents were sent included some or all of the following information (more detail is provided in Table 1):  advance notice of any upcoming tests;  notice of missing homework; and  brief updates on what their child learned in their lessons, with conversational prompts (these subject texts were sent on a three-weekly rotation\x97science one week, maths the next, and English the following week, then the fourth week it was back to science)."
"It was intended that parents would receive approximately 65 texts over the academic year. For example, per subject, ten texts would be sent regarding upcoming tests and conversation prompts were to be sent once per week during non-testing weeks (totalling five texts over the academic year). It was also planned that parents would receive five texts per subject for feedback on their child\x92s grades or test results, and five texts concerning their child\x92s attendance at school, but these texts were not sent as part of the project. There were no targets or standards set for the frequency of missing homework text messages as this is dependent on whether homework is submitted or not.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"the current intervention, PEP, seeks to promote the engagement of parents in their child\x92s learning by building on communication processes and technologies that are already familiar to schools. Here, through the creative use of text messages from the school, parents are kept informed about various aspects of their child\x92s attendance, learning, and progress.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Teachers were required to attend 1.5 days training\x97one full day in September 2014 and a further half- day training event the following January. At these events schools were introduced to key members of the project delivery and evaluation teams as well as provided with information packs for their teachers and administrators. Training was digitally recorded and made available to all schools. The training events were hosted by the project delivery team and attendees were provided with an overview of the study, its design, and the associated timelines. Schools were introduced to an updated version of Schoolcomms specifically developed for schools taking part in the study. Download and set- up instructions were provided by way of written information and a practical demonstration. Attendees were also provided with detailed written and verbal instructions on how to implement the five components of the programme: texting (1) advance notification of upcoming assessments (ideally approximately ten test texts per subject per year), (2) the results of tests (n=5), (3) missing homework alerts (as appropriate), (4) conversational prompts regarding recent learning (n=5), and (5) attendance summaries (n=5).[¬e]"']
int_approach_info: There is no teaching approach, just informative text messages to parents.
int_when_info: It is not specified when exactly the text messages are sent.
int_dur_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" the programme was delivered from September 2014 to July 2015[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" It was intended that parents would receive approximately 65 texts over the academic year. [¬e]"']
int_cost_ht: ['Page 35:\n[¬s]"Cost The cost of the programme as delivered in this one-year trial is estimated at £7.55 per pupil. This figure includes the cost of teacher training as well as costs associated with implementing the programme (both project delivery team support and text message costs). Teacher training Schools required one and a half days of supply cover to enable a representative to attend the training sessions (one full day in September and one half day in January). Not all schools will have required cover, however and at an estimated cost of £200 per day this will have cost each school approximately £300 per teacher. Project delivery team support[¬e]"', 'Page 36:\n[¬s]"The project delivery team employed a number of research assistants (RAs) to support the implementation of the programme within schools. Each RA cost approximately £20,000 for the duration of implementation and supported eight schools. This equates to a total cost of approximately £72,500 across 29 schools\x97£2,500 per school. One school did allocate paid teacher time to support the intervention and this cost the school in the region of £2,000. Text messages Once teachers are trained to deliver the programme the ongoing costs to the schools are the text messages in addition to an annual Schoolcomms license fee of £1,500 per annum. Parents should be sent an average of 65 texts per year, and at £0.05 per text this is the equivalent of £3.25 per child. Thus, for a typical secondary school with 1,000 pupils, the cost to the school is: \uf0b7 £3.25 x 1,000 (for 65 texts to 1,000 pupils); \uf0b7 £2,500 for project support; \uf0b7 £300 to cover one teacher to attend 1.5 days training; and \uf0b7 £1,500 annual Schoolcomms license fee. This comes to a total of £7,550 per school (£7.55 per pupil) for the first year of implementation, with ongoing yearly costs relating to the cost of the text messages (£3.25 per pupil) and the annual Schoolcomms license fee (£1.50 per pupil). Table 13 summarises cumulative and average costs per year.[¬e]"']
out_eval_raw: ['Is this an EEF evaluation?', 'An organization commissioned independently to evaluate']

int_desc_info: 'Programmed materials, called Practice Exercises, were developed to be used by parents or other non-professionals. Each exercise provided practice on one of the four objectives of the reading programme. These objectives were to read on sight ninety one-sylable words, to recognize and say twelve vowel-consonant ending sounds, and to blend previously learned beginning and ending sounds to sound out new words. A Practice Exercise contains twenty items that require the pupil to select or construct a response to a printed stimulus. Verbal directions are given by the parent who reads a script printed on the exercise itself. For each of the ten program units taught during the year, there are eight Practice Exercises. Parents were instructed to have the children work through each twenty-item Practice Exercise twice for a total of forty responses each day.' (p. 438)
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"ted Learning Pro- gram was designed to enable school personnel to establish a system to help parents effectively instruct their pri- mary-grade children in basic skills at home.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]"The Parent-Assisted Learning Pro- gram was designed to give pupils class- room-related practice at hom[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The programme introduced, explained and modelled the paired reading process
(Topping & Lindsay, 1992). Special emphasis and time was given to mediation skills.
Parents observed and practised these skills with the children during the sessions using
a variety of books including those from the local library. The importance of reciprocity,
built up through discussion and interaction with the child around the story, title and
illustrations, was stressed. Special emphasis was placed on intentional mediation of
meaning. This included actively discussing and thinking about meaning before, during
and after reading; directing attention to meaning and context, highlighting features that
might otherwise go unnoticed; reciprocal questioning around the reading material;
prediction with regard to the story line and vocabulary; relating the reading material to
the child’s present experience and knowledge; assisting insights into less explicit levels
of meaning; and using contextual clues in thinking about and understanding the reading
matter. To assist interaction the specific use of purposive questioning (How?, What?,
Where?, When? Why? Who?) was modelled and practised by both the parents and
children.
Throughout, the emphasis was on promoting brief, regular, positive and enjoyable
interaction around the reading activity. While a minimum of reading together for five
minutes a day, five days a week, was suggested, flexibility around time spent on the[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"activity, depending on both the child and the parent’s willingness to continue, was
encouraged. The short duration of the reading activity was important to accommodate
parents who had expressed concerns about time pressures. Parents were encouraged to
discuss their difficulties and successes with the programme leader as well as the class
teacher and principal.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 120:
[¬s]"The Home Enrichment Learning Program (HELP) is a plan
designed to train parents of first-graders who are
participating in a beginning reading program in the Madison
County Public School District in ways to aid their children
with beginning reading at home. Parents participating in
this program will be trained during a home visit by the
researcher. Each session will last approximately one hour
and will consist of a discussion of the following topics:
I. The Importance of Reading
II. Factors Associated With Learning to Read
A. Reading to Children
B. Available Reading Materials in the Environment
C. Parents as Reading Models
D. Available Writing Materials in the Environment
E. Responsive Persons in the Environment
III. The Shared Book Experience (Discussion and
Demonstrat ion)
Information promoting reading in the home and
reinforcing the important points outlined in the home
training session will be periodically mailed to the parent.
Parents will be contacted by phone 2-3 times during the
semester and reminded of the things they should do with
their children at home to help in the reading process. Any
questions they might have will be answered at this time.[¬e]"', 'Page 121:
[¬s]"PROMOTTNG READING AT HOME
As a parent, you are your child's first-ana most important-
teacher. There are many simple things you can do at home to help
your child become a better reader.
1 . Reading to your child everyday is the most important thing you
can do to help your child learn to read. Fifteen minutes per day
can make a difference in whether or not your child becomes a
reader. Men should make an extra effort to read to their children.
Most primary teachers are women, so many young boys associate
reading with women or schoolwork. If you are not a good reader,
you can still encourage your child. As your children learn to
read, ask them to read to you. Talk about books they have read.
Ask a friend or relative to read to your child.
♦Try to set aside a regular time everyday for reading aloud.
Bedtime is a natural read-aloud time. Other busy families
might read aloud at breakfast or just after dinner.
♦Sit close to your child when you read a book. This will be a
special time that many children always remember.
*Talk about the pictures. Occasionally, ask questions such as,
"What do you think will happen next?"
♦Reading should be fun and enjoyable. Choose stories you like
so that you can read them with enthusiasm.
2. Read yourself. Your actions really do speak louder than
your words. When your child sees you reading the newspaper or
curling up with a book, he or she will want to do the same. Try to
spend some time reading even if you do not enjoy it.
3. Provide your child with many reading materials.
♦Schedule regular trips to the library.
♦Read books, magazines, newspapers, cereal boxes, or anything
that you have in your home.
♦Give books as gifts. Book ownership ls a wonderful way to
encourage reading and this gift can be enjoyed over and over
Ln. Find a special place fo: your child to keep his or her[¬e]"', 'Page 122:
[¬s]"Encourage your child to write. Writing goes hand in. hand with
reading. Provide many types of writing materials for him or her to
use. Some inexpensive examples might include:
*Chalk and a chalkboard
♦Sidewalk chalk
♦"Writing" with a finger in
sand, shaving cream, or
♦Crayons, pencils, paint, markers pudding
♦Used newspaper or computer paper ♦Grocery bags
Make writing meaningful. Some examples of things you and your
child can do together might include:
♦Write letters to friends and family members.
♦Make lists for everything. You and your child can make lists
of groceries to buy, items to pack for a trip, books to get
at the library, and chores to be done. Refer to these lists
often, and ask your child to check off items as they are
purchased, packed or accomplished.
♦Read the television guide together to plan what television
shows you will watch.
5. Talk to your child. Discuss things that happen during the
day. Answer your child's questions. Talk about books you are
reading. Encourage your child to read and praise him when he does.
Make reading a privilege. Say, "You can stay up 15 minutes later
tonight if you're reading in bed." Or you might say, "Because you
helped with the dishes, I have some time to read you an extra
story."
Becoming a good reader requires practice, and most children
will want to practice only if the task is enjoyable. Make reading
fun!!!
Reading is very important. It is the key to a successful
future. Parents are in a wonderful position to make a real and
lasting difference in the lives of their children. It just takes
a few minutes everyday to help your child develop into a reader.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Little Books (McCormick & Mason, 1990) are designed to capitalize upon what zhildren know.
Little Books (a) are thematic and contain familiar topks to increase the child's expectafion that text
should make sense; (b) are written using everyday high-frequency content words to il.cllitate links
between spoken and written language; (c) have a strong fit between illustrations and text to make clear
that both text and picture frame the meaning; (d) are written using phrases and simple sentences to
promote comprehension at the minimal discourse level; (e) feature a story that ends with a culminating
idea to create a sense of intrigue or amusement and provide text closure; and (f) have a guided-
participation model (Rogoff, 1986) underlying the presentation and practice of-the books in order to
foster children's confidence.[¬e]"']

['Page 11:

covariance (ANCOVA) was used to partition out
the variability in treatment phase reading
achievement that was attributable to baseline
reading achievement."
"ANCOVA provided
increased precision in estimating treatment effect
(Cook & Campbell, 1979). ANCOVA was
appropriate for reading level because student
reading achievement during baseline was
correlated significantly with reading achievement
during treatment (r = .69 to .97; p < .05).[¬e]"']

terest; or choose words from the word lists in their packets.
