int_desc_ht:
['Page 58:
[¬s]"The parent component of the intervention program was two workshops, held on each
Wednesday evening of the two-week camp for children. The first workshop briefly discussed
the important role that parents play in supporting children's academic success and included a
broad overview of research evidence linking parental involvement to academic achievement.
The bulk of the workshop, however, was spent discussing parent-child shared book reading.
The workshop included a discussion on the role of shared book reading for children's reading
development and information on how to choose books that support early reading acquisition."
"parents learned that shared
book reading is important for growth in children's vocabulary, general knowledge, and
comprehension, and children's increasing understanding of print concepts and syntactic
structure. The workshop presentation discussed how each of these skills is related to
children's reading ability. The group also discussed the importance of creating a relaxed,
supportive environment during shared book reading, and that parents need to structure the
book reading experience so that children enjoy reading."
"To ensure that children are enjoying books, the workshop presented tips for choosing
'good books' - books that children enjoy but are also useful for teaching phonological
awareness and word reading. The workshop included information on the importance of
pattern, of repetitive phrases or words, of lyrical or rhythmic flow in the text, and of content
that appeals to children's interests.
At the end of the first session, the facilitator read each of the five books used for the
children's camp program, demonstrating different characteristics of the books and different
techniques for shared reading. The techniques demonstrated how different types of books
could be used to support growth in children's vocabulary, general knowledge, and
comprehension, and children's understanding of print concepts and syntactic structure[¬e]"', 'Page 59:
[¬s]"Parents were encouraged to be 'expressive' readers so that, in addition to learning emergent
literacy skills, children also would be entertained by the book reading experience."
"The second workshop focused on phonological awareness specifically. This session
included an explanation of phonological awareness and an explanation of its importance for
reading acquisition. Parents learned that there were three types of phonological awareness
(syllable, rhyme, and phoneme) that most often develop in sequence. Parents learned to
recognize their own child's level of phonological awareness and were shown how to focus
children's learning at their current level."
"The second part of the workshop presented different types of phonological awareness
skills. To demonstrate, the workshop facilitator described the phonological awareness items
in the assessment battery. The test battery includes tasks where children are asked to identify,
segment, and blend phonological units. Parents also learned that other tasks, not used in this
assessment battery, ask children to manipulate or substitute phonological units. Parents were
asked to consider these types of activities (identifying, segmenting, blending, and
manipulating) when thinking of different phonological awareness activities for their own"
"At the end of this workshop, parents worked in small groups to discuss the ways that
phonological activities could be incorporated into home routines. After working in small
groups, parents presented different phonological awareness activities that they could perform
at home. Working together with the facilitator, the group considered ways to modify
children's favourite activities into 'phonological' activities, for example, while playing catch,
try to say another rhyming word each time you catch the ball; see how many rhyming words
the group can come up with in a row[¬e]"', 'Page 60:
[¬s]"At the end of the second workshop, the facilitator again stressed the importance of
parents taking an active role in supporting their child's learning. It was acknowledged that
some parents may have had negative experiences at school, but that children deserve a 'fresh
start', and that parents should not project their own negative attitudes about education onto
children. The final point encouraged parents to try the phonological awareness activities and
book reading activities with their own children; the activities may seem silly to adults but
children often really enjoy them - or at the very least, enjoy that parents are engaged in the
activities with them.[¬e]"']

int_cost_ht:
['Page 177:
[¬s]"This project could not have been completed without the generous support of several
community partners. The local school boards (public and Catholic) contributed space in their
schools to host the summer program and provided the salary for one teacher in each program.
The local Ontario Early Years Centre (OEYC) was the other key stakeholder in the area.
Early Years Centres provide free programs to children from birth to six years and their
parents/caregivers across the province. The local OEYC provided program materials (craft
supplies, books, toys, etc) and provided the salary for one teacher in each program. Our role
as researchers was to conduct the pre- and post-testing assessments of child participants and
to provide the salary for the third program staff. In collaboration with our other partners, we
developed a program curriculum that was based on current research, that was compatible
with the school board's literacy objectives, and that would be enjoyable for young children."
"Working together, the project partners were able to pool resources to provide a
program for children and parents that would not have been possible independently."
". In a time of reduced funding and higher service
expectations, community collaborations may be the best way to support children and families.
Integrating the intervention components into the RTI model[¬e]"', 'Page 179:
[¬s]"The intervention components could be combined to create two different models of
RTI. Under the first model, parent workshops would be available to all parents and caregivers
of children six years and younger. Workshops would be offered intermittently throughout the
year to provide support to parents of all young children. The child camp would serve as tier"
"In the second RTI model, parent education would serve as the first two of the
intervention. JK teachers could refer parents of children showing early difficulties with
emergent literacy skills or children who appear to have little support completing homework
activities. A series of parent workshops (perhaps more than the two sessions described in the
current project) would be provided to parents during the JK school year.[¬e]"', 'Page 180:
[¬s]"A community partnership composed of researchers, school boards,
and a community service provider, was created to pool individual resources and build on
expertise to offer the program free of cost to children identified by teachers as showing early
signs of reading difficulties.[¬e]"']
int_cost_info: only some information about the costs, or possible costs, but not detailed and not total cost. In addition, some resources were polled together by the specific community & in conjunction with what already had been in place, so unknown how these costs could be transferale

int_name_info: There were two intervention conditions  - Low-Level Distancing Group - High-Level Distancing Group
int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Intervention was based in part upon Sigel’s distancing theory, with 20 mothers encouraged
to increase inductive, responsive, and complex behavior and the other 20, only inductive and responsive
behavior.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"Low-Level Distancing
The training encouraged this group of
mothers to increase three behaviors: (a) asking
questions, forming statements directed at ask\xad
ing, interrogating, or inquiring; (b) talking
more, verbally informing, giving, offering
information; and (c) talking with, expanding on
what the child had previously said and/or
expressing approval about what the child had
done."
"The trainer encouraged these mothers to
increase the level of distancing strategies as
well as the frequency of questions and
responsiveness. They were encouraged to: (a)
ask what and why questions that focused the
child’s attention on a major part of the picture;
(b) talk more—label, describe (e.g., size,
color, number, shape, taste), and identify
functions and classes of items; (c) talk with
(same as the low-distancing group); and (d) talk
about “things in general” by noting the general
function and classification of items (i.e., cars
and trucks are used for traveling; apples and
oranges are fruits)."
"High-distancing mothers were provided train\xad
ing in the question phase that encouraged a
three-level prompt system: (a) repetition (same
as low-distancing group); (b) orienting com\xad
ments—highlight relevant parts of the picture
(e.g., written question, “Who is the farmer?”
orienting comment, “Which man do you think
is the farmer?”); (c) focusing comments—
suggestions about specific cues to the solution
(e.g., written question, “What happened in the
story?” focusing comment, “Weren’t they
building something?”).[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The training encouraged this group of
mothers to increase three behaviors: (a) asking
questions, forming statements directed at ask\xad
ing, interrogating, or inquiring; (b) talking
more, verbally informing, giving, offering
information; and (c) talking with, expanding on
what the child had previously said and/or
expressing approval about what the child had
done. Mothers were provided these rules
verbally and pictorially. A self-analysis train\xad
ing procedure was employed in which the
trainer and mother reviewed the previously
video-taped session, with the trainer identifying
maternal utterances that matched the rules. The
trainer reinforced the mother for using these
rules and assisted her in modifying remaining
utterances to match the provided rules. Exam\xad
ples employed by the trainer were concrete,
focusing on labeling specific items."
"High-Level Distancing
The trainer encouraged these mothers to
increase the level of distancing strategies as
well as the frequency of questions and
responsiveness. They were encouraged to: (a)
ask what and why questions that focused the
child’s attention on a major part of the picture;
(b) talk more—label, describe (e.g., size,
color, number, shape, taste), and identify
functions and classes of items; (c) talk with
(same as the low-distancing group); and (d) talk
about “things in general” by noting the general
function and classification of items (i.e., cars
and trucks are used for traveling; apples and
oranges are fruits). The same training proce\xad
dure as summarized previously for the low-
level distancing group was used."
"High-distancing mothers were provided train\xad
ing in the question phase that encouraged a
three-level prompt system: (a) repetition (same
as low-distancing group); (b) orienting com\xad
ments—highlight relevant parts of the picture
(e.g., written question, “Who is the farmer?”
orienting comment, “Which man do you think
is the farmer?”); (c) focusing comments—
suggestions about specific cues to the solution
(e.g., written question, “What happened in the
story?” focusing comment, “Weren’t they
building something?”). Mothers were informed
that the use of orienting and focusing strategies
would give children clues to the correct answer
while at the same time modeling a problem\xad
solving strategy. This prompt system was
based in part on* Bee et al.'s (1969) specificity
scale and Blank’s (1973) simplification proce\xad
dures.[¬e]"']
int_training_info: Maternal behaviour was the focus of this intervention, therefore, they had to be trained to implement this.
int_approach_info: Mothers would work with their own children.
parent_partic_info: The children's mothers were trained to provide the intervention to their children.

All story-visit sessions were transcribed in standard orthogra\xad phy from audio tapes dubbed from the video tapes. Utterances were segmented primarily by apparent terminal intonation context. A second observer evaluated all transcripts for accuracy. Discrepancies were noted and resolved. Mater\xad nal and child measures were collected1 from the story and question sessions."
"Coding was conducted by 10 trained observ\xad
ers, with interrater reliability averaging 97%"

checks were conducted every tenth session.
Rate measures were calculated for higher order
concepts and feedback measures to decrease
the effects of time.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Even Start, a federally supported\nfamily literacy program[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Even Start, a federally supported family literacy program providing early childhood education, adult education, parenting education, and joint parent–child literacy activities to children and parents from low-literate families."
"The evaluation of
18 Even Start projects followed 463 families for 2 years[¬e]"', 'Page 2:
[¬s]"The research described here is based on an experimental eval-
uation of the nation’s largest family literacy initiative—the Even
Start Family Literacy Program. Established in 1989, Even Start has
the primary goal of improving the academic achievement of low-
income young children and their parents, especially in the area of[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"reading"
"Even Start projects are mandated to offer the instructional
activities for parents and children that were described above. They
also are required to avoid duplication of services by building on
existing community resources such as local adult education pro-
grams or Head Start. Even Start projects decide on the frequency
and duration of instruction, whether instruction is primarily center
based or home based, and whether to invent educational curricula
from scratch, use published curricula, or use a hybrid of ap-
proaches. On the basis of the availability of local instructional
services and the extent to which those services are perceived to be
of high quality, project staff decide which activities will be sup-
ported by Even Start funds and which will be provided by collab-
orating agencies. Projects offer screening and referral services
such as referrals for mental health counseling, services to battered
family members, employment services, and screening or treatment
for chemical dependency. Projects also offer support services such
as transportation, flexible scheduling, child care, nutrition assis-
tance, health care, and meals to help families participate in the
program.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"Thus, previous research about family literacy instructional com-
ponents shows that high-quality intensive early childhood educa-
tion programs can indeed produce short-term cognitive benefits for
low-income children. However, expectations about the effective-
ness of parenting education and adult education programs for
parents should be modest at best, with subsequent effects on their
children being even more unlikely, leading Ramey, Ramey,
Gaines, and Blair (1995) to question the premise that adult-focused
programs can ever have benefits for children.
In spite of the questions raised by this research evidence, the
family literacy model hypothesizes that the instructional services
described above will be more effective when integrated into a
unified program, that some synergy is expected from receiving the
combination of services, and that the integration of instructional
services will lead to enhanced outcomes both for children and
parents. The present study investigates the validity of these
hypotheses.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"a federally supported
family literacy program[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"On the basis of the availability of local instructional
services and the extent to which those services are perceived to be
of high quality, project staff decide which activities will be sup-
ported by Even Start funds and which will be provided by collab-
orating agencies.[¬e]"']
int_prov_info: Intervention is supported by federal US government. Explicit information about who provides the intervention e.g. delivery of workshops/projects is not given.
int_training_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Even Start projects are mandated to offer the instructional
activities for parents and children that were described above. They
also are required to avoid duplication of services by building on
existing community resources such as local adult education pro-
grams or Head Start.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Even Start has no guidelines for amount of
service or for length of participation other than the requirement
that families participate in all four core instructional services and
that services are of “sufficient intensity and duration” (U.S. De-
partment ofEducation, 2002, p. 2).[¬e]"']

that families participate in all four core instructional services and
that services are of “sufficient intensity and duration” (U.S. De-
partment ofEducation, 2002, p. 2). Thus, the amount of instruction

families participate in Even Start instructional services for as much
or as little as they wish. Compared with the amount of instruction

[¬s]"However, parents and children participate in only a fraction of the hours offered: 30% of adult education, 24% of parenting education, 25% of parent–child activities, and 30% to 62% of early childhood education, depend- ing on the child’s age (see Figure 4)."

Even Start classrooms had books displayed and available for
children to use, and all had a library or reading corner (St.Pierre et

classrooms had an area set up for writing"
"Even Start projects across the nation use a combination of
existing early childhood curricula and locally developed materials.
Of the 18 projects participating in this evaluation, 7 reported that

w.highscope.org), and 3 reported that they used the Creative Cur-
riculum (see www.teachingstrategies.com)."

indicate that 35% of the families that were recruited for the

ipated so little that project staff did not consider them to be real
participants in the program."
"These two data sources, from parents and projects, show that
although Even Start families participated in instructional services
at substantially higher rates than control families, some control
families did receive the same types of services that Even Start
families received. Thus, and as intended, the comparison made in
the evaluation is not between families that participated fully in
Even Start and families that participated in no educational or social
services whatsoever. Rather, the comparison is between families
that enrolled in Even Start and participated at whatever level they
wished and families that did not enroll in Even Start but who
participated in whatever mix ofeducational and social services that
they obtained on their own, in the absence of any assistance from

base_diff_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Even Start and con-
trol families were statistically equivalent at the time of randomization and
at the pretest. Group equivalence at the time of randomization is guaran-
teed, within known statistical bounds, by proper implementation ofrandom
assignment and a sufficiently large sample size. Ten percent of the families
included in the random assignment were lost between the time of random-
ization and time of pretest. This attrition occurred equally in the Even Start
and control groups, and an analysis of pretest data shows that Even Start
and control groups did not differ significantly on the percentage of families
where Spanish was spoken at home, families where English was spoken at
home, Hispanic families, parents with a high school diploma or a GED,
single-parent households, employed parents, households with an annual
income less than $9,000, and child gender (see Table 1).[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" a model of encouraging parental participation which had been employed, by Dyson and Swinson (1982).[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"Before the project began the parents of the children who were to form the experimental group were invited to discuss their child\'s progress with the nursery teacher. At this meeting they agreed to participate in the project and were asked to relate their current practice of reading stories to their children. The parents were then invited to a group meeting in school the following week. At this meeting the aims of the project were outlined and a brief account of good practice when reading to children was given. A short video of a mother reading to her child was shown, which provided a basis for a discussion. The emphasis of the advice was to make reading an enjoyable experience for both mother and child, and to use it as an opportunity to extend their child\'s language skills. A booklet containing this advice was also given to the parents. After this meeting whenever the parents collected or delivered their child to the nursery class they were encouraged to choose a book together from a special display. A simple library system was used to keep track of the books and in addition each parent was given a record card on which to enter the name of the book and write any comments about it if they wished.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"1"\n" To encourage the parents of children attending the nursery to read stories to their children every day. 2. To evaluate the effect this approach has on the children\'s language skills and their subsequent performance on transfer to infant school. 3. To provide evidence for the effectiveness of this type of approach for nursery school practice.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"The intervention was
delivered between 2001 and 2002, and extended over the course of three terms. In the
ﬁrst term, parents were offered 12 sessions on behaviour management; in the second
term, 10 sessions of the literacy programme; and in the third term, 6 sessions combining
elements from both. Each session lasted approximately 2.5 hours. The structure of both
elements of the programme was similar, combining centre training with home visits.
Detailed manuals and videotapes of both programmes were created to facilitate
replicability and a number of professionals have already been trained to deliver the
programme around the UK[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Opstap Opnieuw / ‘‘Step-up Anew’’ (alternative to the well-known HIPPY, Israeli Home Instruction Program for Preschool Youngsters, Lombard, 1981)
int_desc_ht: NA
int_desc_info: Families were eligible for the programme and evaluation study if both parents were born in Morocco, had received less than 10 years of formal education, and had a child in the age range of 4–5 years.  (Description on page 150.) The core of the programme was a structured curriculum built on the matrix of proximal goals, specifying all kinds of educational activities to be carried out collaboratively at home by mother and child. The curriculum covered two years (effectively, 30 weeks in each year) and was presented to the mothers on weekly instructions and worksheets, which specified activities for five days each week. In total, there were 150 planned activities per year. Carrying out the daily activities was estimated to take about 20 minutes each day. In addition to the worksheets, the programme provided all kinds of materials to be used in the activities, such as pencils, scissors, audiotapes with nursery rhymes and songs, and picture books. Instructions to the mothers about how to carry out the activities were written on instruction sheets in clear, simple language and, in view of the low literacy skills of many of the target mothers, supported by pictorial illustrations. For fully illiterate mothers, stories and songs were also made available on audiotape. Worksheets, instruction sheets, materials, books, and tapes were all attractively designed. Picture books were written by well-known authors of children’s books.  The mothers were supported by paraprofessional aides who were to explain the worksheets and demonstrate appropriate interactional behaviour. These paraprofessionals were experienced mothers themselves, belonged to the same communities as the target families, lived mostly in the same neighbourhoods, spoke their languages, but were on average slightly better educated. Paraprofessional aides were recruited locally by the coordinators, from the Moroccan target group. They were usually known by the coordinators because of their active participation in the neighbourhood. They received an introductory training (8–10 days) and were further trained on the job by their local coordinator. According to the plan, the paraprofessionals visited the families every two weeks (planned number of visits  15 in each year) or, alternatively, organised small group meetings in a nearby neighbourhood centre. In addition to instructing and supporting the mothers, the paraprofessionals were also asked to keep records of the actual implementation of the programme activities, thus being an essential instrument of the programme’s implementation strategy and implementation monitoring system.  In addition to the support by paraprofessionals, the programme also organised monthly group meetings (planned number of meetings  12 per year) for the mothers in a neighbourhood centre, headed by the local coordinator. A portion of the group meetings was used for providing additional information on the worksheets. There was also time for discussing general child-rearing themes brought in by the parents. However, the main purpose of the group meetings was to provide information about general principles of authoritative and emotionally supportive, sensitive-responsive interaction styles. A videotape showing a model mother-child interaction was used for demonstrating these principles. In view of the fact that the target groups spoke different languages, the programme was made available in Dutch, Turkish, and standard Arabic.

Finally, a parent/guardian signature is requested on each

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]"Each week a trained paraprofessional visited the home of each experimental-
group mother and presented a task to her. Prior to the onset of the program the
paraprofessionals had been trained for a period of three weeks.
The tasks were presented in a simple, uniform style so that the mother
understood their purpose and subsequently was able to teach them to her child.
The tasks consisted of:
1. Name of the task -- title.
2. Why? -- a simplified explanation of the purpose of the specific lesson, i.e.,
what the child would learn and how both the child and the mother would benefit
fxom it.
3. What? -- references to materials necessary for teaching the specific lesson,
such as paper, pencil, crayons, etc.
4. How? -- step-by-step instructions as to the teaching of the specific lesson.
Suggestions were made as to the kinds of questions a mother could ask the
child, and ways of arousing the child's interest in the learning of the new task.
5. What else? -- this section suggested to the mother a variety of ways in which
she could add to and enhance the learning of a specific task. It allowed both the
mother and the child to explore the many ways and situations in which newly-
learned tasks or skills could be applied.
Some of the teaching ideas that were incorporated into the weekly tasks
were: development of concepts such as time and size; recognition of colors and
shapes; familiarity with letters and number symbols, etc.
The presentation of the task was followed by a role-playing session in
which the paraprofessional assumed the role of the child, the mother the role of
teacher. The mother then had a chance to practise what she had just been
taught. This was followed by a general discussion of the previous week's task,
the general objectives of the program, and other related matters. An appoint-
ment was then made for the next visit and the mother was reminded to teach the
new task to her child during the following week, and if possible to repeat it more
than once. In addition, the mother was encouraged to involve the rest of the
family in the new learning situation. Each home visit lasted from 15 to 60
minutes.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 27:
[¬s]"Type 4 - Learning At Home - one area within Epstein's
framework that involves partnerships in which the school
provides families with information and ideas about how to help
students with schoolwork at home"
"TIPS (Teachers Involve Parents In Schoolwork - a teacher-
parent-student partnership process -- designed, implemented, and
tested by Epstein and Salinas with the help o f teachers -
featuring prototype homework assignments that require students
to talk to someone at home about something interesting that they
are learning in class. The purpose o f this process is to keep[¬e]"', 'Page 28:
[¬s]"students and their families talking about schoolwork at home,
thus helping families stay informed and involved in their
children's learning[¬e]"', 'Page 30:
[¬s]"To start, teachers were introduced to the TIPS process by this
researcher, who familiarized them with the concept o f school and family
partnerships, and with TIPS Math activities including their purpose, design, and
strategies for implementing the TIPS activities in their classrooms. Each o f the
teachers was given a set o f TIPS Math activities coinciding with the concepts to be
studied during the third marking term, and was asked to select two TIPS Math
activities for students to complete at home, weekly."
"These homework activities
were to reinforce the mathematics concepts being studied in the classroom. The
activities sent home were designed to be completed with family interaction.
A parent orientation was conducted to introduce parents or the primary
caregiver to the concept of school and family partnerships. Additionally, teachers
were asked to help the researcher communicate with parents as needed to assure the[¬e]"', 'Page 31:
[¬s]"completion o f the TIPS activities. This communication was accomplished by means
o f letters or notes home, and through in person and phone conversations with
primary caregivers or other family members."
"As each mathematics activity was completed, the teacher was asked to treat
TIPS Math assignments in the same manner used to collect and mark other
homework, with one difference. Teachers were asked to initiate a discussion that
permitted students to share their experiences with family interactions, emphasized
the importance o f family involvement, and mentioned the school's appreciation for
the family involvement (Epstein & Salinas, 1992).[¬e]"', 'Page 69:
[¬s]"Each TIPS Mathematics
activity followed the same format which included: Student's Name; Date; I. Look[¬e]"', 'Page 70:
[¬s]"This Over; II. Now Try This; III. Practice Section; More Practice; Answers To
Now Try This; IV. Home To School Communication. A sample TIPS Mathematics
activity is included in Appendix A.[¬e]"', 'Page 71:
[¬s]"Teachers were asked to use TIPS activities directly correlated to the concepts
being studied in class. They were asked to communicate with primary caregivers as[¬e]"', 'Page 72:
[¬s]"Initially, primary caregivers were expected to attend the orientation meeting,
or complete an alternative introduction to the project accomplished by viewing a
video o f the original orientation.
Throughout the nine week study, families were asked to set aside the time

teachers' opinions about family involvement in student learning[¬e]"', 'Page 30:
[¬s]"The TIPS Homework Project developed by Epstein and Salinas
(1992) was selected for this study because the three major purposes of the TIPS
Math activities -- to encourage students to complete their homework and to improve
their attitudes, behaviors, and achievements, to create useful two-way
communications about schoolwork, and to promote good interactions at home
between students and their families about schoolwork -- correlated with this
researcher’s objectives to investigate the effects o f using school and family
partnerships to improve student achievement and motivation, and to examine the
effects o f school and family partnerships on parent attitudes toward school and
teacher attitudes toward family involvement.[¬e]"']

comp_anal_ht:
['Page 29:
[¬s]"This particular population was identified for several reasons. First, in attempting to ensure reliability and validity of data collection, these schools were selected because they have similar socioeconomic demographics."
"Thirdly, the decision to use only
four classes at each school was made because, while one o f the schools had seven
classes of fourth graders and the other school eight classes, the classes were grouped
homogeneously by reading ability. In attempting to create a more representative
population, it was assumed that by eliminating the top and the bottom groups at both
schools, a more heterogeneous sample would result. Finally, in the school division
where this study was proposed, the Iowa Test of Basic Skills (ITBS) is given to all
students in grades one through twelve, yearly, and selected grade level results are
publicized at the state and local levels.[¬e]"']
comp_var_rep_ht:
['Page 29:
[¬s]"Finally, in the school division where this study was proposed, the Iowa Test of Basic Skills (ITBS) is given to all students in grades one through twelve, yearly, and selected grade level results are publicized at the state and local levels. The fourth grade results on this test are published both statewide and divisionwide. This school division’s fourth grade results are well below the state average. Since a major purpose o f this study was to examine the effects of using family involvement to improve student achievement, and these fourth graders' test scores indicate a need for improvement, it seemed logical to focus on efforts designed to raise student achievement of fourth graders."

int_name_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"interactive book reading program for children
at home and at school called dialogic reading[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"sound foundations[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"The program fea-
tured small group reading in the classroom (e.g., four children to
one adult, with a frequency of three to five times per week) and
involved one-on-one reading at home with the same books that
were used in the classroom.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]", a phonemic
awareness curriculum that was developed and tested in Australia
(Byrne & Fielding-Barnsley, 1991, 1993). The sound foundations
curriculum began in February in each classroom and continued
through June. Teachers introduced children to seven consonant
sounds (s, m, p, g, I, t, sh) in the beginning and ending positions in
words and to two vowel sounds (a and e) in the beginning position
only."
"As an example of how this element of the curriculum
worked, on Monday of beginning /s/ week, children were invited
individually to walk forward from the group and to find objects
with names beginning with the /s/ sound (e.g., seal or scissors) in
a large colorful poster. On Wednesday, the students were asked to
find objects on their own worksheets that began with the /s/ sound
and to color the objects with crayons. On Friday, the students were
asked to play a version of the game hot potato in which the
children sat in a circle and passed a bean bag to each other while
music was playing. The child who was holding the bean bag when
the music stopped had to find something in the classroom the name
of which began with /s/. Our adaptation of sound foundations"
"included introducing the children to the manuscript letters that
correspond to the curriculum sounds. We incorporated letters into
the curriculum by placing a large poster with the letter for the week
in the classroom and having the teacher give completion prompts
to the children in the form, "This is the letter S; it says
."[¬e]"']

int_prov_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"an interactive book reading program for children
at home and at school called dialogic reading. The program fea-
tured small group reading in the classroom (e.g., four children to
one adult, with a frequency of three to five times per week) and
involved one-on-one reading at home with the same books that
were used in the classroom. Both parents and teachers were trained
in how to read dialogically by means of a 20-min video (White-
hurst, 1992a), which was coupled with brief role-playing and
discussion following exposure to the video.[¬e]"']

of the school year. The first wave of parents was trained at parent
meetings in their children's Head Start centers.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"For the school reading condition, the teacher or aide engaged in dia- logic book reading with children in groups of no more than 5 children at a time. Shared reading sessions were scheduled to occur daily for about 10 min per reading group."
" We avoided"
"picture books that relied heavily on the written text for the sense or pleasure of the book because such books generate more straight reading by adults and decrease a young child's opportunities to participate ac- tively in story time."
" "
" Children in the school plus home reading condition experienced small-group dialogic reading in school under the same conditions as children in the school reading condition. In addition, a parent or pri- mary caretaker ofeach child was trained to use dialogic reading at home with the same videotape that was used for teachers and similar training procedures. Parents were trained at their child's day-care center. Train- ing sessions were held in late afternoon, just before closing time. Chil- dren were cared for by the day-care staff while a number of parents watched the training video simultaneously and then engaged in one-on- one or two-on-one role play with a trainer. As was the case for the teach- ers, parent training was delivered in two assignments, separated by 3 weeks. Parents were given three books at each assignment to be used at home during dialogic reading. The books were given to the families to keep. The books were those also used by a child's teacher during dialogic reading. Parents were encouraged to read to their child daily. [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"developing a practical interactive book reading intervention for day-care, preschool, and Head Start settings."\n" Training of readers in the principles of dialogic reading[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Teachers were trained to read to children in a dialogic reading style by using a videotape training method (Arnold et al., 1994; Whitehurst, Arnold, & Lonigan, 1990) modeled closely on our previously used di- rect training procedures (Valdez-Menchaca & Whitehurst, 1992; Whitehurst, Falco, et al., 1988). The videotape contained two assign- ments, described in Table 3. The procedures for the adult in Table 3 were presented as a set of rules and were followed by taped vignettes of adult-child book reading that exemplified those rules. Afinalsection of the videotape consisted of vignettes of inappropriate adult-child book reading. Teachers were asked by the trainer to criticize the readers in the vignettes in terms of the rules of dialogic reading and to indicate what the adult reader should have done differently in response to the child. Following the videotape, the trainer engaged in role play with the teach- ers being trained, which involved presenting various examples of child behavior and giving the teacher feedback on her use ofthe dialogic read- ing rules. The whole training sequence took about 30 min per trainee for Part 1 and 20 min for Part 2. Part 1 and Part 2 training were sepa- rated by 3 weeks. Teachers were trained during the school day. "\n" Parents were trained at their child\'s day-care center. Train- ing sessions were held in late afternoon, just before closing time. Chil- dren were cared for by the day-care staff while a number of parents watched the training video simultaneously and then engaged in one-on- one or two-on-one role play with a trainer. As was the case for the teach- ers, parent training was delivered in two assignments, separated by 3 weeks. Parents were given three books at each assignment to be used at home during dialogic reading. The books were given to the families to keep. The books were those also used by a child\'s teacher during dialogic reading. Parents were encouraged to read to their child daily.[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Parents and teachers were asked to fill out a daily log sheet of when reading occurred and the particular books that were used. The teachers\' reading log also included information on which teacher or aide con- ducted the reading session and which children were included in the reading group. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:\n[¬s]"There was substantial variability in the fidelity with which teachers followed the reading or activities schedule that was con- veyed to them as part of training, as determined by the reading and activity logs that the teachers completed. Mean number of reading sessions per child in the intervention conditions per center ranged from 4.57 to 22.75 (M = 16.63, SD = 8.24). The difference in reported reading frequency across centers is statis- tically significant, F(4,43) = 86.87, p < .001. This appears to be an important variable in that correlations between the outcome measures and the frequency with which individual children in the intervention conditions were reported to have participated in dialogic reading sessions at school were significant at p < .05 for the One Word posttest and follow-up, the Our Word, and the PPVT-R follow-up. The frequency with which children in the school plus home condition were read to at home by parents also showed substan- tial variability (M = 34.58, SD = 13.46, range = 8-53). Corre- lations between this measure for children in the school plus home condition and the seven outcome measures showed p < .05 effects for the Our Word, One Word follow-up, and the ITPA follow-up.[¬e]"']
out_eval_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Each child\'s assessment session was conducted by one of six doctoral students in clinical psychology.[¬e]"']

['Page 3:
[¬s]"this replication was motivated
by the observation that substantial numbers of children enter
kindergarten with low levels of the skills that are prerequi-
sites to school success.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"The first element of the intervention was an
interactive book-reading program for children at home and school
called dialogic reading. It featured small-group reading in the[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"classroom (i.e., approximately four children to one adult, with a
frequency of three to five times per week). It also involved
one-on-one reading at home with the same books that were being
used in the classroom. Both parents and teachers were trained in
how to read dialogically using a 20-min video (Whitehurst, 1994a,
1994c), coupled with brief role playing and discussion following
exposure to the video. Details of the dialogic reading intervention
are reported in Whitehurst, Epstein, et al. (1994)."
"he second element of the intervention was our adaptation of
Sound Foundations (Byrne & Fielding-Barnsley, 1991b), a phone-
mic awareness curriculum that has been developed and tested in
Australia (Byrne & Fielding-Barnsley, 1991a, 1993, 1995). The
Sound Foundations curriculum began in February in each interven-
tion classroom and continued through June. Teachers introduced
children to seven consonant sounds corresponding to the letters s,
m, p, g, 1, t, and sh in the beginning and ending positions in words
and two vowel sounds corresponding to the letters a and e in the
beginning position only. As an example of how this element of the
curriculum worked, on Monday of beginning /s/ week, children
were invited individually to walk forward from the group and find
objects with names beginning with the /s/ sound (e.g., seal or
scissors) on a colorful large poster. On Wednesday, they were asked
to find objects on their own worksheets that began with the /s/
sound and color the objects with crayons. On Friday, they were
asked to play a version of hot potato in which the child who was
holding the beanbag when the music stopped had to find something
in the classroom whose name began with the /s/ sound.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"mothers in this group met weekly for an hour a week for four
weeks. The first session provided information about the skills involved in reading (meaning,
grammar, and phonic cues), ways to introduce a book, and to encourage good reading habits, as
well as how to select an appropriate time and place for the daily reading session. The second
session showed mothers how to select a book of appropriate difficulty. In the third session the
tutoring procedures described by Glynn, McNaughton, Robinson, and Quinn (1979) were
explained and practised. Mothers were taught what to do when children read correctly and
when children made errors. The fourth session focused on information and practice, with feed-
back from the trainer. During each session printed notes were distributed and homework was
provided. Mothers were encouraged to implement the new techniques as they were introduced.[¬e]"']

ment in their children's reading on their reading achievement[¬e]"', 'Page 3:

short programme training mothers as home reading tutors[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 17:
[¬s]"This phase of the program consisted of establishing regular weekly contacts with
the home-instructor. Typically, the home-instructor was to bring the child to the PPRC
to discuss the previous week(s) progress. At these meetings, the home-instructor was
encouraged to demonstrate a brief lesson with the child under observation of the reading
specialist. In this way it was possible to observe the interaction between the home-
instructor and child. In some instances Step IV was accomplished through home visits
by the staff of PPRC. Home visits were initiated as a response to the problem of keeping
appointments by some home-instructors.[¬e]"', 'Page 18:
[¬s]"In addition to the individual guidance approach of PPRC staff to home-instructors,
periodic group meetings were held for PPRC home-instructors. Typically these meetings
were held in the evening and involved group discussion about children, individual
problems and strategies, as well as promotion of social exchange among home-instructors.[¬e]"']
